title: 107_s1942
content: The "Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002" is also known as the Biodiesel Used as Fuel section, which provides incentives for biodiesel use as a fuel by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002, also known as the Biodiesel Used as Fuel section, offers incentives for biodiesel use by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The biodiesel fuels credit for the taxable year equals the biodiesel mixture credit, which is calculated based on the biodiesel mixture rate for each qualified mixture and the gallons of the mixture used. The biodiesel mixture rate is 1 cent for each whole percentage point of biodiesel in the mixture, up to 20 percentage points. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides incentives for biodiesel use by offering a biodiesel mixture credit based on the biodiesel mixture rate for qualified mixtures. The rate is 1 cent for each whole percentage point of biodiesel in the mixture, up to 20 percentage points. Qualified biodiesel mixtures are those sold or used by the taxpayer producing the mixture for fuel purposes. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers incentives for biodiesel use through a biodiesel mixture credit. The credit is based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture, up to 20 percentage points. Biodiesel used in the production of a qualified mixture must be sold or used for fuel purposes in the taxpayer's trade or business. Casual off-farm production of a qualified mixture is not eligible for the credit. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 provides incentives for biodiesel use through a biodiesel mixture credit. The credit is based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture, up to 20 percentage points. Casual off-farm production of a qualified mixture is not eligible for the credit. The amount of the credit for biodiesel is reduced to account for any benefit from other tax exemptions. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 incentivizes biodiesel use through a biodiesel mixture credit based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture, up to 20 percentage points. Biodiesel is defined as monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids derived from various vegetable oils for use in diesel engines. The Biodiesel Promotion Act of 2002 offers incentives for biodiesel use through a biodiesel mixture credit based on the percentage of biodiesel in the mixture, up to 20 percentage points. Biodiesel is defined as monoalkyl esters of long chain fatty acids derived from vegetable oils like rapeseeds, safflowers, flaxseeds, rice bran, and mustard seeds. The biodiesel must meet registration requirements set by the EPA and ASTM D6751. If biodiesel is separated from a qualified biodiesel mixture or used for purposes other than fuel, a tax is imposed based on the biodiesel mixture rate and the number of gallons in the mixture. A tax is imposed on a person who uses biodiesel for purposes other than fuel, based on the biodiesel mixture rate and the number of gallons in the mixture. Applicable laws and penalties apply to this tax as if imposed by section 4081. Rules similar to section 52 apply for estates and trusts. There is an election to not apply the biodiesel fuels credit. A taxpayer may elect to have the biodiesel fuels credit not apply for any taxable year, with rules similar to section 52 applying for estates and trusts. The election must be made before the expiration of the 3-year period beginning on the last date for filing the return for the taxable year. The biodiesel fuels credit election must be made by the deadline for filing the return, as specified by the Secretary. The section does not apply to fuel sold after December 31, 2012, and the credit is treated as part of the general business credit. Conforming amendments are also made to the tax code. The biodiesel fuels credit election deadline is specified by the Secretary. Amendments are made to the tax code, including no carryback of the biodiesel fuels credit before January 1, 2003. Amendments to the tax code include allowing the biodiesel fuels credit determined under section 40A to be carried back to a taxable year before January 1, 2003. The tax code amendments include a reduction in motor fuel excise taxes on biodiesel mixtures, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. This involves a new subsection (f) in Section 4081 of the Internal Revenue Code, allowing for a reduced tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures. The tax code amendments introduce a reduced tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures, applicable to the removal or entry of biodiesel or diesel fuel for producing biodiesel mixtures. The tax code amendments introduce a reduced tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures, applicable to the production of biodiesel mixtures from diesel fuel. Definitions and rules from section 40A also apply. The tax code amendments introduce a reduced tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures, applicable to the production of biodiesel mixtures from diesel fuel. Definitions and rules from section 40A also apply, with certain rules to be followed for this subsection. Conforming amendments are made to sections 4041 and 6427 of the tax code. The tax code amendments introduce a reduced tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures, applicable to the production of biodiesel mixtures from diesel fuel. The rates under subsection (a) are reduced by any applicable biodiesel mixture rate. Section 6427 is amended to include provisions for biodiesel mixtures. The amendments introduce a reduced tax rate for qualified biodiesel mixtures produced from diesel fuel. The effective date for these changes is for fuel sold after December 31, 2002, and before January 1, 2013. Transfers from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds will offset reductions in Highway Trust Fund receipts due to these amendments. Transfers from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds will offset reductions in Highway Trust Fund receipts due to amendments made before January 1, 2013. The transfers will be based on estimates by the Secretary of the Treasury and adjusted for any errors.
